questions.question: Deductions FOR adjusted gross income are also known as:

options.B: Above-the-line deductions

questions.explanation: Deductions for AGI are called above-the-line deductions because they are subtracted from gross income to arrive at AGI (the 'line'). These are more valuable than itemized deductions because they reduce AGI, which affects eligibility for various tax benefits.
questions.tip: FOR AGI = above the line. FROM AGI = below the line (itemized or standard).

questions.question: Eligible educators can deduct unreimbursed classroom expenses up to:
questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 62(a)(2)(D), eligible educators (K-12 teachers, counselors, principals who work at least 900 hours) can deduct up to $300 of unreimbursed expenses for classroom supplies, books, and professional development as a deduction FOR AGI.
questions.tip: Educator expense deduction = $300 for K-12 teachers (above the line).

questions.question: Contributions to a traditional IRA are:

options.B: Potentially deductible depending on income and retirement plan coverage

questions.explanation: Traditional IRA contributions may be fully deductible, partially deductible, or not deductible depending on the taxpayer's income, filing status, and whether covered by an employer retirement plan. The deduction phases out at certain income levels for covered taxpayers.
questions.tip: Traditional IRA deduction depends on income + whether you have employer plan.

questions.question: The maximum student loan interest deduction is:
questions.explanation: Taxpayers may deduct up to $2,500 of interest paid on qualified student loans as a deduction for AGI. The deduction phases out at higher income levels and is not available to taxpayers who are claimed as dependents.
questions.tip: Student loan interest = up to $2,500 (above the line), subject to income phase-out.

questions.question: For divorce agreements executed before 2019, alimony paid is:

options.B: Deductible as an itemized deduction
options.C: Deductible FOR AGI by the payor

questions.explanation: For divorce agreements executed before January 1, 2019, alimony paid is deductible FOR AGI by the payor and includible in the recipient's gross income. This treatment was eliminated for agreements executed after 2018.
questions.tip: Pre-2019 divorce: alimony deductible (FOR AGI). Post-2018: no tax effect.

questions.question: Contributions to a Health Savings Account (HSA) are:

options.B: Deductible FOR AGI within annual limits

questions.explanation: HSA contributions are deductible FOR AGI up to annual limits ($3,850 for self-only coverage, $7,750 for family in 2023). Distributions for qualified medical expenses are tax-free, making HSAs triple-tax-advantaged.
questions.tip: HSA = triple tax benefit: deduct contributions, tax-free growth, tax-free medical distributions.

questions.question: A self-employed taxpayer can deduct what portion of self-employment tax as a deduction FOR AGI?
questions.explanation: Self-employed taxpayers may deduct 50% of self-employment tax as a deduction FOR AGI. This represents the employer-equivalent portion since employees do not pay tax on the employer's share of FICA taxes.
questions.tip: Self-employment tax: pay 15.3%, deduct half (employer portion) FOR AGI.

questions.question: A self-employed individual may deduct health insurance premiums paid for themselves and family:

options.B: FOR AGI up to the net profit from self-employment
options.C: Only if they have no employees

questions.explanation: Self-employed individuals may deduct 100% of health insurance premiums paid for themselves, spouse, and dependents as a deduction FOR AGI. The deduction cannot exceed the taxpayer's net self-employment income from the business.
questions.tip: SE health insurance = 100% deductible FOR AGI, limited to SE net profit.

questions.question: The maximum SEP-IRA contribution for a self-employed taxpayer is:

options.C: 25% of net self-employment earnings up to $66,000 (2023)

questions.explanation: SEP-IRA contributions are limited to 25% of net self-employment earnings (after the SE tax deduction) up to the annual dollar limit ($66,000 in 2023). The contribution is deductible FOR AGI.
questions.tip: SEP = 25% of net SE earnings, max $66,000 (2023). Deduct FOR AGI.

questions.question: A penalty for early withdrawal of savings from a time deposit (CD) is:

options.B: Deductible as an itemized deduction

questions.explanation: The penalty for early withdrawal of savings from a time deposit (such as a CD) is deductible FOR AGI. This is reported on Schedule 1 and offsets the interest income that must be reported gross on the tax return.
questions.tip: Early withdrawal penalty on savings = deductible FOR AGI.

questions.question: Under current law, the moving expense deduction is available to:

options.A: All taxpayers who move for employment
options.B: Only members of the Armed Forces on active duty who move due to military orders
options.C: Any employee moving more than 50 miles

questions.explanation: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act suspended the moving expense deduction for most taxpayers from 2018-2025. The only exception is for members of the Armed Forces on active duty who move pursuant to military orders.
questions.tip: Moving expense deduction: military only (2018-2025). Suspended for others.

questions.question: The domestic production activities deduction (Section 199) is:

options.B: Repealed by TCJA but replaced by the Section 199A deduction for pass-through entities

questions.explanation: The Section 199 domestic production activities deduction was repealed by TCJA effective 2018. It was partially replaced by the Section 199A qualified business income deduction, which provides a 20% deduction for pass-through business income.
questions.tip: Old Section 199 repealed → new Section 199A (QBI deduction) for pass-throughs.

questions.question: Rental real estate losses may be deducted FOR AGI by:

options.B: Active participants up to $25,000 subject to AGI phase-out

questions.explanation: Taxpayers who actively participate in rental real estate activities may deduct up to $25,000 of rental losses against non-passive income. This allowance phases out between $100,000 and $150,000 of modified AGI.
questions.tip: Active rental losses: $25,000 allowance, phases out at $100K-$150K AGI.

questions.question: Contributions to an Archer MSA are:

options.A: No longer permitted for new accounts
options.B: Deductible FOR AGI for eligible individuals

questions.explanation: Archer MSAs (predecessors to HSAs) are still available for existing accounts, and contributions are deductible FOR AGI. However, new Archer MSAs generally cannot be established—most taxpayers now use HSAs instead.
questions.tip: Archer MSA = grandfathered accounts. HSA is the current equivalent.

questions.question: Attorney fees paid in connection with employment discrimination cases are:

options.B: Deductible only as itemized deductions

questions.explanation: Attorney fees and court costs paid in connection with claims of unlawful discrimination, whistleblower awards, and certain other employment-related claims are deductible FOR AGI under IRC Section 62(a)(20) and (21).
questions.tip: Discrimination case attorney fees = deductible FOR AGI (not limited by 2% floor).

questions.question: Ordinary and necessary business expenses of a sole proprietor are:

options.B: Deductible FOR AGI on Schedule C
options.C: Not deductible until the business is sold

questions.explanation: Sole proprietors deduct ordinary and necessary business expenses on Schedule C, which flows to Form 1040 as a deduction FOR AGI. The net profit or loss reduces or increases AGI directly.
questions.tip: Schedule C expenses = FOR AGI. Net profit goes to Form 1040.

questions.question: Reforestation expenses may be deducted FOR AGI up to:
questions.explanation: Taxpayers may deduct up to $10,000 per year of reforestation expenses (planting or seeding for timber production) FOR AGI. Amounts exceeding $10,000 are amortized over 84 months beginning in the month incurred.
questions.tip: Reforestation: $10,000 current deduction FOR AGI; excess amortized 84 months.

questions.question: Travel expenses of National Guard or reserve members are deductible FOR AGI if:

options.A: The travel is within 50 miles of home
options.B: The travel is more than 100 miles from home and involves overnight stay
options.D: The member is on active duty

questions.explanation: National Guard and reserve members may deduct travel expenses FOR AGI when traveling more than 100 miles from home to perform services as a reservist. The deduction is limited to the federal per diem rate for lodging, meals, and incidentals.
questions.tip: Reserve travel deduction: 100+ miles from home, limited to federal per diem rates.

questions.question: The maximum annual IRA contribution for a taxpayer under age 50 in 2023 is:
questions.explanation: For 2023, the maximum IRA contribution is $6,500 for taxpayers under age 50 (increased to $7,500 for those 50 and older with catch-up contributions). This limit applies across all traditional and Roth IRAs combined.
questions.tip: 2023 IRA limit: $6,500 under 50, $7,500 age 50+. Combined for all IRAs.

questions.question: Net capital losses in excess of capital gains may offset ordinary income up to:

options.B: $3,000 ($1,500 if married filing separately)

questions.explanation: Net capital losses can offset ordinary income up to $3,000 per year ($1,500 for married filing separately). Excess losses are carried forward indefinitely to future years, retaining their short-term or long-term character.
questions.tip: Capital loss deduction: max $3,000/year against ordinary income. Excess carries forward.

questions.conceptTested: Jury duty pay remitted to employer
questions.question: Jury duty pay that an employee is required to remit to their employer is:

options.B: Deductible FOR AGI

questions.explanation: When an employee receives jury duty pay but must turn it over to the employer (who paid regular salary during jury service), the remitted amount is deductible FOR AGI. This prevents double taxation of the same income.
questions.tip: Jury pay given to employer = deduct FOR AGI (avoids double tax on income).

questions.question: A self-employed individual's Keogh plan contribution is calculated based on:

options.B: Net self-employment earnings reduced by the Keogh deduction itself and 50% of SE tax

questions.explanation: The Keogh contribution base is net self-employment earnings reduced by the deductible portion of SE tax. The contribution itself is also part of the calculation, creating a circular calculation that results in an effective rate lower than the stated percentage.
questions.tip: Keogh base = net SE income - ½ SE tax. The math is circular (20% plan ≈ 18.59% effective).

questions.question: The maximum employee elective deferral to a SIMPLE IRA for a taxpayer under age 50 in 2023 is:
questions.explanation: SIMPLE IRA employee contributions are limited to $15,500 for 2023 ($19,000 for age 50+). This is lower than 401(k) limits. Employers must make either matching contributions (up to 3%) or non-elective contributions (2% of compensation).
questions.tip: SIMPLE IRA: $15,500 employee limit (2023). Lower than 401(k)'s $22,500.

questions.question: A self-employed individual with a Solo 401(k) can contribute as both employee and employer, with total contributions limited to:

options.B: $66,000 plus catch-up if age 50+ (2023)

questions.explanation: Solo 401(k) allows employee deferrals ($22,500 or $30,000 if 50+) plus employer contributions (25% of compensation), with total limited to $66,000 ($73,500 if 50+) for 2023. This allows larger retirement savings than SEP-IRAs for some self-employed individuals.
questions.tip: Solo 401(k): employee deferral + employer contribution = up to $66K (2023).

questions.question: Passive activity losses can offset:

options.B: Only passive activity income

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 469, passive activity losses can only offset passive activity income. Excess losses are suspended and carried forward to offset future passive income or recognized when the activity is disposed of in a fully taxable transaction.
questions.tip: Passive losses = offset passive income only. Suspended until disposition.

questions.question: The at-risk rules limit losses to:

options.A: The amount of the initial investment
options.B: The amount the taxpayer has at risk (economic risk of loss)
options.C: The fair market value of the investment

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 465, losses from business or investment activities are limited to the amount the taxpayer has at risk—generally the amount of money and adjusted basis of property contributed, plus amounts borrowed for which the taxpayer is personally liable.
questions.tip: At-risk = can only deduct what you could actually lose (your economic exposure).

questions.question: The traditional IRA deduction phase-out for a married taxpayer filing jointly who is an active participant in an employer plan begins at MAGI of approximately:
questions.explanation: For 2023, the IRA deduction phase-out for active participants in employer plans begins at $116,000 MAGI (MFJ) and is fully phased out at $136,000. Non-active participant spouses have higher thresholds ($218,000-$228,000).
questions.tip: IRA deduction phase-out (MFJ active participant): $116K-$136K for 2023.

questions.question: A non-working spouse can contribute to an IRA if:

options.A: The working spouse has sufficient earned income to cover both contributions
options.B: The non-working spouse has at least $6,500 in income

questions.explanation: A spousal IRA allows a non-working spouse to contribute to an IRA based on the working spouse's earned income. The couple must file jointly, and the working spouse must have earned income at least equal to the combined IRA contributions.
questions.tip: Spousal IRA: working spouse's income supports non-working spouse's contribution.

questions.question: Under current law, a net operating loss (NOL) can:

options.A: Be carried back 2 years and forward 20 years
options.B: Only be carried forward indefinitely, limited to 80% of taxable income

questions.explanation: Post-TCJA, NOLs can only be carried forward indefinitely (no carryback for most taxpayers) and are limited to 80% of taxable income in the carryforward year. Special rules apply for farming losses and certain disaster losses.
questions.tip: NOL (post-TCJA): forward only, 80% of taxable income limit per year.

questions.question: The excess business loss limitation under Section 461(l) limits non-corporate taxpayer business losses to:

options.B: $289,000 single / $578,000 MFJ (2023, indexed for inflation)
options.D: There is no limit on business losses

questions.explanation: Section 461(l) limits excess business losses for non-corporate taxpayers to $289,000 (single) or $578,000 (MFJ) for 2023, indexed for inflation. Disallowed losses become NOL carryforwards. This applies after passive loss rules.
questions.tip: Excess business loss cap: ~$289K single / ~$578K MFJ. Excess becomes NOL.

questions.question: Under the hobby loss rules, expenses from an activity not engaged in for profit:

options.A: Are fully deductible against hobby income
options.B: Cannot offset hobby income (deductions not allowed under TCJA)
options.C: Are deductible as itemized deductions without limit

questions.explanation: Under TCJA, hobby expenses are no longer deductible (miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to 2% floor were eliminated). However, hobby income must still be reported. This creates a particularly unfavorable result for hobby activities.
questions.tip: Hobby income = taxable. Hobby expenses = not deductible (TCJA). Worst of both worlds.

questions.question: The simplified method for the home office deduction allows a deduction of:

options.A: Actual expenses allocated to office space
options.B: $5 per square foot up to 300 square feet ($1,500 maximum)
options.C: A flat $2,500 regardless of office size

questions.explanation: The simplified home office deduction method allows $5 per square foot of qualified business use space, up to a maximum of 300 square feet ($1,500 maximum deduction). The regular method requires calculating actual expenses and allocating based on square footage.
questions.tip: Simplified home office: $5/sq ft, max 300 sq ft = $1,500 max deduction.

questions.question: A qualified performing artist can deduct employee business expenses FOR AGI if:

options.A: They have any income from performing
options.B: They meet AGI and multiple employer tests

questions.explanation: Qualified performing artists can deduct employee business expenses FOR AGI if: (1) AGI is $16,000 or less before the deduction, (2) they had at least two employers, (3) expenses exceed 10% of gross income from performing, and (4) they file jointly or are unmarried.
questions.tip: Performing artist deduction: AGI ≤ $16K + 2 employers + expenses > 10% of performing income.

questions.question: Contributions to a defined benefit plan for a self-employed individual are:

options.B: Based on actuarial calculations to fund promised benefits
options.C: The same as defined contribution limits

questions.explanation: Defined benefit plan contributions are determined actuarially based on the benefits promised at retirement. Contributions can exceed defined contribution limits because they must be sufficient to fund the promised benefit, making them attractive for older self-employed individuals.
questions.tip: Defined benefit = actuarial calculation. Can exceed DC limits for older, high-income self-employed.

questions.question: Fee-basis state or local government officials may deduct their employee business expenses:

options.B: FOR AGI
options.C: Not at all under current law
options.D: Only if they exceed 2% of AGI

questions.explanation: Fee-basis state and local government officials (paid on a fee basis rather than salary) are one of the limited categories of employees who can still deduct unreimbursed employee business expenses FOR AGI, similar to qualified performing artists and reservists.
questions.tip: Fee-basis government officials = one of few employee groups with FOR AGI expense deduction.
